heading: 2.7 Standardizing data
text:
‚Äôve mean centered data, can go one step divide standard deviation. results something often called z-score. process converting variables original units z-scores called standardizing data.\[
Z = \frac{\left(X - \overline{X}\right)}{SD(X)}
\]useful? One reason remove units measurement facilitate comparisons variables. Suppose \(X\) represents height inches. numerator (\(X - \overline{X}\)) units inches. standard deviation \(SD(X)\) also units inches. divide, units go away z-score left without units, sometimes called ‚Äúdimensionless quantity‚Äù.Suppose female United States 6 feet tall (72 inches). Suppose female China 5‚Äô8 tall (68 inches). absolute terms, American woman taller Chinese woman. ‚Äôre interested knowing woman taller relative respective population?mean height American woman 65‚Äù standard deviation 3.5‚Äù mean height Chinese woman 62‚Äù standard deviation 2.5‚Äù. (numbers aren‚Äôt perfectly correct, ‚Äôre probably close-ish.)Calculate z-scores women.woman taller relative population?Although z-scores don‚Äôt technically units, can think measuring many standard deviations value lies mean.z-score value equals mean?meaning negative z-score?z-score American woman 2. means height measures two standard deviations mean.real-world data, use technology . temperature measurements New York 1974. (daily highs across six-month period.)calculate mean standard deviation:average high 78 degrees Fahrenheit standard deviation 9.5 degrees Fahrenheit.just subtract mean, get mean-centered data.also divide standard deviation, get standardized variable (set z-scores). Note extra parentheses make sure get order operations right. subtract first, divide whole mean-centered quantity standard deviation.easier way R use scale command. (Sorry, output little long. Keep scrolling .)Although outputs formatted little differently, can go back check sets numbers match .mean standardized variable? know ?Let‚Äôs calculate variance standardized variable. , ‚Äôll note mean \(\overline{X}\) just number. Also, standard deviation \(SD(X)\) just number. make calculation easier understand, let‚Äôs just substitute letters easier work :\(M = \overline{X}\)\(S = SD(X)\).Remember, \(M\) \(S\) constants.Now need calculate \(Var(Z)\). ‚Äôll first couple steps. take , using variance rules earlier chapter, simplify expression get numerical answer. sure justify step citing rule invoked get .\[\begin{align}
Var(Z) &= Var\left(\frac{\left(X - \overline{X}\right)}{SD(X)}\right) \\
    &= Var\left(\frac{\left(X - M\right)}{S}\right) \\
    &= Var\left(\frac{1}{S}\left(X - M\right)\right) \\
    &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]get answer 1. standardized variable always variance 1. important fact future chapters.

heading: 3.3 Covariance rules
text:
‚Äôll think variance covariance rules one big list. left Rule 4, now ‚Äôll introduce Rule 5.Rule 5\[
Cov(X, X) = Var(X)
\]words, Rule 5 states covariance variable just thing variance variable. quite remarkable! means variance really just special case covariance.Explain Rule 5 true. (Hint: think calculate \(Cov(X, X)\) using either formula table‚Äî!)Rule 6\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{1}\right)
\]words, say covariance symmetric.Explain Rule 6 true. (, think formula table‚Äî!)next four rules analogous similar rules variance (Rule 1, Rule 2, Rule 3, Rule 4).Rule 7Suppose \(C\) ‚Äúconstant‚Äù variable, meaning always value (rather variable contain lots different numbers). ,\[
Cov\left(X, C\right) = 0
\]always, try explain rule. Give intuitive explanation rule ‚Äú‚Äù true. think computationally, thinking either formula table‚Äî!Rule 8\[
Cov\left(X_{1} + X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) + Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]appreciate longer restriction relationships among variables involved. Rule 2 worked two variables independent. hand, Rule 8 works combination variables, matter relation.Even satisfying next rule:Rule 9\[
Cov\left(X_{1} - X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) - Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Yay! minus sign behaves sensibly now! course, since covariances can positive negative (unlike variances always positive!) can safely subtract two without worry. rule, like Rule 8, depend \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent. can two variables.versions rules addition subtraction side, just minor variations Rule 8 Rule 9, ‚Äôre worth mentioning separate rule. Remember covariance symmetric, can always swap things left right comma.\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2} \pm X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) \pm Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Rule 10If \(\) number,\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) =  Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)  
\]rule also sensible. Instead Rule 4 takes number \(\) pulls \(^{2}\), Rule 10 just pulls single factor \(\) (either slot).Just couple rules. talking independence conjunction Rule 8 Rule 9. leads directly interesting super-important rule:Rule 11If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = 0
\]Rule 11 true, intuitively?‚Äôs interesting note rule works one way. words, know two variables independent, can conclude covariance zero. However, know covariance zero, doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean two variables independent. ‚Äôll see example later chapter.Finally, one rule rule :Rule 12For two variables \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\):\[
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) =
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]brings practically everything know together one rule!Proving Rule 12 give us good practice type manipulation ‚Äôll need future chapters. goes. first steps, name rule ‚Äôre invoking. , ‚Äôll pick thread follow last steps .\[\begin{align}
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) &= Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, aX_{1} + bX_{2}) \\
    &= Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, aX_{1}) + Cov(aX_{1} + bX_{2}, bX_{2}) \\
    &=  Cov(aX_{1}, aX_{1}) +
        Cov(bX_{2}, aX_{1}) + \\
    &   \qquad Cov(aX_{1}, bX_{2}) +
        Cov(bX_{2}, bX_{2}) \\
    &= \quad ???
\end{align}\]‚Äôll need rules calculations future chapters. Rather search Chapter 2 chapter, ‚Äôve gathered rules one convenient place Appendix .

heading: A Variance/covariance rules
text:
Rule 1If \(C\) constant, \[
Var\left(C\right) = 0
\]Rule 2If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Var\left(X_{1} + X_{2}\right) =
Var\left(X_{1}\right) + Var\left(X_{2}\right)
\]Consequence Rule 1 Rule 2:\[
Var\left(X + C\right) = Var\left(X\right)
\]Rule 3If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Var\left(X_{1} - X_{2}\right) =
Var\left(X_{1}\right) + Var\left(X_{2}\right)
\]Rule 4If \(\) number,\[
Var\left(aX\right) = ^2 Var\left(X\right)
\]Rule 5\[
Cov(X, X) = Var(X)
\]Rule 6\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{1}\right)
\]Rule 7If \(C\) constant, \[
Cov\left(X, C\right) = 0
\]Rule 8\[
Cov\left(X_{1} + X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) + Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Rule 9\[
Cov\left(X_{1} - X_{2}, X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right) - Cov\left(X_{2}, X_{3}\right)  
\]Consequence Rule 6, Rule 8, Rule 9:\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2} \pm X_{3}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) \pm Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{3}\right)  
\]
- Rule 10If \(\) number,\[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) =  Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)  
\]Rule 11If \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\) independent, \[
Cov\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right) = 0
\]Rule 12For two variables \(X_{1}\) \(X_{2}\):\[
Var(aX_{1} + bX_{2}) =
    ^2Var(X_{1}) + b^2Var(X_{2}) + 2abCov(X_{1}, X_{2})
\]
